reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a Japanese visual novel developed by stage-nana and written originally in Japanese by Tomo Kataoka. This VN tells the story about the residence of 7th floor Setsumi Sakura and her experience during the last moment of her life.

This game includes both the Narcissu 1st & Narcissu 2nd. 2nd being the prequel and 1st is the main story of Setsumi.
The 2nd tells the story of Himeko Sunohara as her life take a 180 degree turn when she was diagnosed with a diseased that can't be cured, thus she's moved to the 7th floor. Himeko used to work as helper in 7th floor so she kinda used to the situation, but then it all changes when she met Setsumi.

Narcissu 1st set appx. 6-7 years after 2nd. The story is focused on the anonymous Protagonist (just think of him as us) who is terminally ill & Setsumi as both of them realizes their feeling of not wanting to die in the hospital or at home with their respective families. The two of them begin a long journey accross Japan until they find that place...
NARCISSU

I have completed the game 2 years ago and when I found this game on Steam Greenlight, I immediately vote it up as I think this  COULD BE first step of introducing the Visual Novel medium to the West. Currently the game is in Early Access but don't let that bother you because the story itself is completed & translated. I'm also part of the Closed Beta tester and I could say that Sekai Project did a good job of making the game engine compatible with Steamwork.

Definitely a must have if you are an avid VN player or you are interested in this medium, even after 2 years of finishing this, I still get  dem feels  moment :') a Masterpiece indeed!

reviewText: This is a story of disease and suffering; of medication and adverse effects; of thoracotomy scars and cellular poisons; of the living who cannot help but to die and of the dying who cannot help but to live; of a resting place other than on 7F" or "at home".\n\nUsually I would start a review with some sort of story hook
date: an attempt to use my own words to evoke the kind of atmosphere you can expect from the full experience
recommended: something to show you at a glance whether it could really speak to you or whether you would not connect with it at all. In the case of Narcissu 1st & 2nd
hoursPlayed: I feel that no matter how long I try

Instead I will just quote their writing where appropriate and dive straight into the facts myself.\n\nNarcissu and its sequel Narcissu Side 2nd are rather famous kinetic novels (meaning they have no branching story or player choices) with a strong legacy in the VN community. They are known for their use of minimalist visuals

votesTotal: with only very few character CGs inbetween. The soundtrack relies heavily on piano pieces
votesFunny: but also makes use of other instruments in some places
commentsCount: and features two title tracks with Japanese vocals. The engine shows its age in some aspects and does not have a fullscreen mode for example

column17: including save states and a soundtrack menu. As a reader
column18: you have the choice between two different English translations or the original Japanese script
column19: and you can opt to listen to the Japanese voice acting if you so choose.\n\nImagine what it would be like to have your entire life -- your friends
column24: your future -- all taken away from you in a single instant. Imagine a hard
column27: the sharp sting of needles entering your flesh at all hours of the day
column28: the indignity of being woken up just as you are about to fall asleep for incessant vital statistics measurements
column29: the doctors whose names you don't know (but that's okay
column30: because they don't remember your name
column31: either; they just remember you as "the non-small cell lung carcinoma in room 6")
column34:
that you have just about forgotten.

Then you might have some clue as to what it is like to be dying in a hospital.

It would be off the mark to describe Narcissu as an "emotional rollercoaster" since the concept would imply lots of ups and downs
column35: but even though Narcissu ends on a bittersweet note of resolution
column36: it is pretty much devoid of "up" moments. VN connoisseurs might note that this places it in the utsuge genre
column37: everyone else seeking more stories like it now has a keyword to search by.\n\nThe story is about an unnamed young man who falls terminally ill. After all venues of hope are exhausted
column38: he is moved to the hospice ward of the local hospital
column39: where he meets a girl of about his age who conveys to him the unwritten rules of the inhabitants of the 7th floor
column40: of those who are going to die. The two begin a series of awkward non-interactions that culminate in their decision to reject the dichotomy of dying either in the hospital or at home
column41: which kicks off the main arc of the story.\n\nThe way that Narcissu hones in on its themes with every fiber of its being is both its strongest asset and biggest liability. Everything about it
column42: from the background visuals to the character interactions
column43: is teeming with the drabness that you would expect from a story about young people in palliative care
column44: which is not at all a melodramatic "woe is me" caricature of exaggerated sadness and self-pity
column45: but a cold collage of loss and hopelessness rooted in questions that no human should have to ask themselves
column46: such as: What does it even mean to be alive if there can be nothing to look forward to? Both main characters' actions and non-actions need to be viewed through this lens to have any hope of being understood.\n\nIn that sense
column47: Narcissu as a piece of literature is more demanding of your sense of empathy than many other games and visual novels: It could easily be misunderstood as a story trying to show "normal" people what it is like to be terminally ill by taking their hands and walking them through the experience
column48: but in actuality it's closer to a slice-of-life story about people who are terminally ill
column49: that asks you to make the necessary mental steps towards those people on your own if you wish to understand them. In short: This story isn't written for you
column50: it's written for its main characters.\n\nOne example that I can give without veering too far into story spoilers is Setsumi's attitude towards the protagonist. She initially comes across as standoffish and rude
column51: and there's the tacit expectation of a pivotal moment where she finally starts to open up so the "proper" story can start
column52: but that moment never comes. Where a less patient or empathetic reader might leave the story unsatisfied
column53: we can instead take the opportunity to examine Setsumi's behavior with her medical situation in mind
column54: and ponder the way that human relationships develop. Most of us go through life every day making small passing connections to people
column55: but only once in a while do we meet someone we like enough to allow ourselves to be vulnerable around them (which takes courage) in hopes of forging a lasting connection that we can depend on in the future. But what
column57: if there quite literally is no future? Suddenly there is no point in opening up to anyone new. Why bother taking the risk of potentially getting hurt if we will not live to see the reward?\n\nThe novel doesn't spell these details out to you
column58: it asks you to understand the characters on the basis of their actions. Questions like why having a goal is suddenly such a big deal to the protagonist are left up to interpretation. The combination of strong characterization (which if you've seen my previous VN reviews you already know I am crazy for) and partially unapproachable writing is not for everyone
column59: especially not if you are looking for light entertainment
column60: but there is a lot of substance to it for people willing to make the effort.\n\nIn summary
column61: Narcissu is a great visual novel that can be genuinely rewarding to read
column62:
but is ill-suited for those of us with short attention spans.

This is a story of so many things.

But most of all ...

This is the story

of a girl whose heart was standing still

and a boy whose breath was being stolen away

column38: so it was released in both voiced and unvoiced versions
column39: as the author wanted to see how the voices changed people's impression of the work
column40: and subsequently Narcissu Side 2nd is presented similarly. An interesting mirror of that for this release is that two different translations are included: one made with the intent to localize the novel smoothly into English
column41: and one made with the intent to replicate the phrasing of the original as faithfully as possible and paint a mental picture close to what the original author intended. Though I'm writing this review after just one reading
column42: I can see how this approach would add replay value
column43:
and I intend to revisit Narcissu after it stews on me a bit.

Why is this free?
Narcissu is a doujin (or fanmade/amatuer) work and was released for free in Japan. When Sekai-Project announced this Steam release
column44: they said that in the spirit of the original release
column45: Narcissu on Steam would be "As free as Steam would let it be
column46:
so here we are. With that said, don't take the lack of a price as a reflection of quality, because, quite frankly, there's no rule stating that professionals can't do doujin works. The music and voices are especially standout in this release, and a few of the voice actresses have both anime and game roles to their credit.

Conclusion (finally)
Well, I put it at the top for a reason...

This is an excellent release that feels like a labor of love on the part of the author. To me, it stands as a great experiment in minimalist storytelling (especially in the original Narcissu, where I found myself endeared to the characters even with next to no background given about them). Though the novel (and the genre) may not be for everyone, if this feels like your kind of thing, and you have the time to give to reading a great story, I can't not recommend it.

I remember I had this on the GP2X handheld back in 2005, except I only had the 1st story.

I'll be damned if I lie and say this didn't have me cryin' my a** off back then.
One of the best heartwarming stories in a visual novel out there.

The Steam version includes 2 stories. Narcissu which was originally released in 2005 and Narcissu: Side 2nd which was released in 2007. Unfortunately, Narcissu 3rd - Die Dritte Welt was released in 2009 only for PSP.

This is one of the best visual novels on Steam. You should definitely check it out.

reviewText:
There is no fourth time, the third time you are admitted is the last, so prepare yourself.
Narcissu 1st and 2nd is a kinetic novel (Without choices) that portrays the lives of young adults living in the 7th floor of the hospital, the floor in which its residents awaits their deaths. Narcissu 1st and 2nd is a very well made visual novel with highly emotional and wonderfully written storyline, together with the marvelous soundtracks. It puts you in the perspective of people who have a limited amount of time left, people whose future had been denied, people who have nothing left in life, people who live their lives everyday thinking about the day when they will pass on. This Visual Novel is able to invoke a series of emotions and feelings that will linger around even after you completed the story. It is also free of charge, I highly recommend Narcissu if you are a fan of tragic stories or Visual Novels. Definitely one of the better made visual novel there is on Steam.
Right now, do you want me to pull you back, or instead, do you want me to give your back a push?
10/10 will climb Mt Fuji to complain to god again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not a game in the traditional sense. You don't have to navigate, survive, move, do anything at all. Consider it a Visual Novel with no decisions points at all. Think of it as listening to a story.

One playtime of N1 is about 3-4 hours, and N2 approximately double of that. (Notwithstanding the time spent crying) Although the game allows you to save, I suggest taking a Saturday afternoon to finish your first playthrough in one sitting. I wouldn't finish N1 and N2 in a single day though, as both are very emotionally draining.

The music is powerful. It complements the game really well, and is a good setting for the mood. The theme musical piece of N2 is just beautiful, although very painful if you understand the meaning of the lyrics. This is especially more so when you consider Himiko's background. There are only about 10+ song tracks per game though, and each song track is not perticularly long, so you may observe that the music gets repetative after a few hours. The VN offers a choice of voiced and unvoiced version, in Japanese. I love the voice acting. The tone was well done, and you can feel the personality and emotions of the characters through their voices. It was actually painful for me to listen to it, as though someone who was really hurting was there, right in front of me.

The graphics isn't bad, but neither is it great. There's no animation throughout the entire game, it is just a series of largely nondescript scenery artwork. It probably would have been rather weird without the art, though.

There's nothing much I can say of the story without being too spoilerish, so really, just try it out for yourself. Narcissu is a very though provoking piece centering on the topic of death, mainly on the process of dying. I'll not touch on the points raised, leaving the story open to your own interpretation. The writing transported me into their world, made me internalized their emotions as though I was the one actually going through everything. This is a real tear-jerker, although I'm glad its not because it wants to be a tear-jerker. That is to say, the storyline is not written such that it becomes a sad story, rather, the message behind the story generally evokes sad feelings in people.

I've came across people who complained that the story behind N1 was too linear. (I must admit, I was an idiot for missing the blatently smoking Chekov's gun at the beginning) This is not a detective mystery novel, and to put an unexpected twist ending would go against the point of the game. N2 is significantly longer than N1, but touches on more topics as well. It is the prologue of N1, giving more details of unexaplined things which happened in N1, and giving more depth to Setsumi. Even so, it is a distinctly seperate story from N1.

After finishing N2, don't close the game just yet. Go back to the main page, as you've unlocked a short Epilogue/Acknowledgements. It is concluding section from the author, giving us what the ending after N1 would turn out to be.

It would be good to read the game notes too, especially the part about translator's disambiguation of the two translation versions and the choice of voiced or unvoiced versions on which to choose for your first time. For my first playthrough I used a voiced version of Agilis' translation and did it in the order N1 followed by N2. Although the author  suggested playing it in the chronological order (N2 before N1), I recommend going through N1 first. There were limited information about the main character Setsumi, and her backgrounds in N1; I felt this actually helped to focus the story onto the important points. For those who don't like the slight confusion of not knowing the main character's background, go with the author's suggestion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you were sick.
If you were all alone.
If you just accepted it.
If you got to know someone.

This is the story of a little girl with no parents, of a woman who pushed away her friends, of a girl that accepted her fate, and a boy who stood behind, waiting. All of them residents of the 7th floor, the floor for one to await for their turn... to die.

First, its probably better to explain what is Narcissu 2nd, while it's the second game, in reality it functions as a prequel to the first story. While both stories have different points of views, the person connceting them, and the main pillar, is Setsumi, a 22 year old girl (15 on the prequel).

On Narcissu 1st, the story is about a boy (Yuu Atou, although his name is never revealed on both games) who meets Setsumi, a girl who doesn't wants to die neither at home or on the 7th floor.
Narcissu 2nd is about the encounter between Setsumi and Himeko, a woman on her twenties, cheerful and full of energy, who is currently residing on the 7th floor.

While the autor says that in his opinion the playing order should start with the 2nd, I started with the 1st (hadn't noticed that before completing the first game), and with that, I can say that playing the 1st first, and then the 2nd, gives the feeling of so that's how it happened"
date: and it helps to see better some connections between both games. If one decides to start with the 2nd
recommended: in my opinion I think it will give a better connection with Setsumi and probably more emotional impact (although it still gives you one whatever game you decide to start first).\n\nIt's surprising that a free visual novel is so well built

reviewText:
Narcissu (ナルキッソス Narukissosu?) is a FREE visual novel by the dōjin group stage-nana, telling the story of a terminally ill young man and woman. It was made with the NScripter engine.

Narcissu -Side 2nd- is the prequel to the visual novel Narcissu, produced by Stage-nana. The game serves as a prequel to the first game, the plot revolves around Setsumi, the female heroine from the original visual novel, and the people and circumstances that formed the character presented in the first game.

Narcissu 2 is set about six or seven years before the events of the original Narcissu, while Setsumi was still just a regular outpatient living at home near the hospital. We meet Himeko, a former 7th floor helper at the hospital. Cheerful and full of energy, no one expected that she would one day be a patient in the same ward that she had spent so much time volunteering at. One summer day, while Setsumi was going to the hospital for an examination, Setsumi meets Himeko, and a long summer begins…

FEELS. This game is wonderful. The story touched my heart. It's sad and mysterious, but very beautiful. There aren't many pictures in this novel, but it's still pretty good. The music was perfect. I definitely put a few game's original tracks to my favorite music list. I really became attached to the characters and it's very sad that their fate wasn't that good. I absolutely LOVE this visual novel. If you like sad visual novels then I strongly recommend to play this game.
voteText: 30 of 38 people (79%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Narcissu 1st is the story about disease, about two young people are dying because it's their fate, right from the start.
Every ordinary thing in our daily life seems to be boring and trivial. But for them, every little thing could make the rest of their days in this world meaningful, an evidence that they are alive even they know it's just temporary and meaningless after all. They've dreamed of a normal life so that they can live, can become anyone that they want. But it's just a dream, a dream which never come true and at the end, Setsumi cried...
You can believe or not, I know exactly how they feel because I used to be like them. Desperate, impotent, regret, hopeless. This is what you feel when your death comes closer and closer. Even the little details they put into the story, the driver license, swimming suit can make me shed a tear because I empathize with their feeling, their pains.
I was too shocked by the ending.But finally, Setsumi has beat her fate. Dying on 7F or at home...nope, none of them. You know, no matter what happen, we always have a choice and this world isn't fair so we can only choose the way to live and die without regretting...we'll never know what happen tomorrow.
voteText: 19 of 20 people (95%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
If you knew you were going to die, would you cry? or would you curse your fate?

Narcissu is the story of two terminally ill patients of the 7th floor, that decide to leave the hospital for a trip.
We follow their journey through Narcissu and in Narcissu 2nd, a prequel to the first, we witness a similar story.

This VN is short, in around 5 to 6 hours, I finished both games and the epilogue and acquired all the achievements.

The story is very beautifull, but somber, which is expected when the main protagonists are barely hanging on to life.

The style is very minimalistic, most of the art is scenery. A lot of people complained that the art style was not to their liking, but I think it's very pretty, serene and delicate. It's definitely better in Narcissu 2nd.

The music is wonderful and calming, I love it and bought it instantly. If you like relaxing piano tracks, it's worth the listen. You can access it in the extra menu of the game.

I recommend playing this VN, it's free and it is short enough to occupy you on a rainy afternoon. Though the themes explored in the story are daunting and heatbreaking, it still touches upon something we can all retale to, death.

reviewText:
This is one of the best visual novels a have played, It´s pretty well written and very detailed, with a not very affable or pleasant theme but with a great value.

I would alert that this history is sad, and a lot of people look the whole plot as it, I personally found it at the end as a message of acceptance and optimism, giving a feel of hope, confidence and so  the depart of someone.

The game has some languages support and come with subtitles and also dubbed, It has an amazing soundtrack (too much that I ended buying it lol), I recommend the use of headset while playing, It shows some really good artwork that with combination of the sound effects you can get a good perspective of the protagonist, and also the game now comes with achievements for each chapter you have completed.

I have to say that I don´t consider this a videogame but it can be enjoyable as one, so if you are not in to this kind of stuff, just give it a try now, it´s for free, and I hope you can enjoy it too! :)

Oh, a little note, for me it was pretty slow the moment of changing to the next dialogue, so to do it faster change the speed on menu, also press ¨A¨ to put autoplay mode, It would be even better.

I gave it a 9/10, I really enjoy every moment of it, and had a good time but as I said, I don’t consider it a game but more on a style of a book.

I hope you will have a good time~

reviewText:
Here is a visual novel that differs from the rest. It is an enjoyable, albeit tearful story about two kids slowly dying to unnamed illnesses.

Fans of the genre take note this 'game' isn't like other VNs on Steam. While it has it's moments for making you grin, I should warn that it is, at its heart, a depressing story - not everyone's cup of tea. Having said that I found it artfully executed, tasteful (no excessive sex references or anything of the sort), and a welcome change in mood from other games in my possession.

I don't want to give away the plot, for it is short. What you can expect is a minimalist approach to story-telling - images of scenery and hospital interiors, quiet and terse dialogue, simple yet beautiful characterisations. It has a lot going for it, making it a worthwhile purchase in my mind. The only problem I had was trying to figure out who the protagonist was at certain points in the story, which may have been intentional.

There is also a beautiful mystery if you don't stay attentive, in the form of whether the story-teller is male or female. I only recently learned I had it wrong, but once again this may have been intentional. It may have worked even better had there been no evidence at all, leaving the reader to come up with whatever they prefer.

So sure, it's not your typical visual novel. It isn't interactive in any way. There are no branching possibilities, no choices to be made for different endings. But it does have a lot of things that do work - quality artwork, a decent musical score, and a plot that, in my mind, rivals some of the best short stories and novellas out there today. Worth getting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A story of those who have been denied a future, and what they do with the little time they have left.

First things first: Narcissu is very minimal, even by visual novel standards. There are no carefully detailed character portraits or meticulously crafted scenes. There are no branching paths or any choosing of one's waifus. The minimal-ness is even outright stated by the creator (in the Notes) to be intentional, so as to encourage the reader to visualize for themselves the scenes as they play out. Don't go in expecting this to be something it isn't.

The presentation seeks to evoke the atmosphere of a movie and does so effectively with its use of its (somewhat small) soundtrack, transitions, and screen layout. I recommend just turning on auto-play and watch (or, more accurately, read) the events of the story unfold, just as you would a movie.

It shouldn't need to be said that the main characters of these stories, Setsumi and Himeko for Narcissu 1st and 2nd respectfully, will die. There are no miracles or magic cures, no cheap ways out of their respective predicaments. It is with this in mind that the story really is at its most impactful; two people whose lives have been cut short, due to no fault of their own, and what they do with the precious few moments they have left. There is no angst here, no tantrums or curses or moping or complaining, as the two have long since come to terms with their soon-coming deaths. Instead the focus is on their actions and passing on what little they can to those they will soon be leaving behind. Narcissu 1st focuses more on the person who is dying, their experiences and choices as their death slowly approaches, while Narcissu 2nd focuses on the people around that person, those who will be invariably left behind. The two stories never felt like they were meant to be tear-jerky and never made any cheap stabs at my 'feels'-glands, all tears shed were well-earned by the writer (and translators!).

From a technical standpoint the game itself works fine, if at times a bit wonky. I had a problem where holding down 'ctrl' caused the game to skip forward to the end of a chapter and leave me stuck at the chapter select. Also, I remember seeing a couple of typos here and there.

If you made it this far and like what you've read I cannot recommend this game any more highly, I liked it enough to the point of writing this long-♥♥♥ review as soon as I completed it. Also it's free, so you really have no excuse.

reviewText:
This horrible, horrible visual novel made be cry! As its intention was evoking emotions, it did the job.

Let's get down to business (I will keep this spoiler-free). Narcissu visual novels (VN) are not strictly games: they have no interactive parts whatsoever. You can just click away and the story continues linearly with no choices. Even the achievements are just reading the novels to their ends.

Narcissu (both of them) is a story about people living with a terminal disease. Note the emphasis. It's a highly emotional and tragic story, with death being a constant theme. Nevertheless, the characters lives are what's important.

Curiously, the type of the disease is left unrevealed in all cases, emphasising the life of the person instead of the sickness. At all times the story follows one of the protagonists from their perspective, revealing what goes through their head. (Most) Protagonists and some important characters have voice-overs for their dialogue. Scenes are covered by nice, melodical piano songs and occasional other instruments.

Apart from many other visual novels, the visuals are very simple: usually there's just a serene scene that depicts the place where the events take place e.g. a kitchen or a countryside. There are very few scenes with people. The style didn't appeal to me strongly. However, I think that at important (i.e. dramatic) times the scenes were well done.

A couple of things about 1st and 2nd novels separately. In my opinion Narcissu 1st begins slowly, with the protagonist being admitted to a hospital and angsting away there. In Chapter 1 it seems like nothing is happening and frankly I was bored while reading it. Fortunately, in half-way through Chapter 2 it finally begins happening, so be sure to endure until that time. Narcissu 2nd is better in this respect as it has a branching story line from the beginning with several characters.

While both VNs are originally Japanese, there are fortunately two English translations of Narcissu 1st. The Agilis translation (the one I read thoroughly) has rather lot of typos and in some small parts it is left unfinished. To me it felt rather clunky. Only afterwards I briefly checked the gp32 translation and it turns out gp32 is a more polished and proper" translation to English than Agilis. Narcissu 2nd has only Agilis translation to English that was fortunately a lot better and more polished than the one in Narcissu 1st.

For me
date: Narcissu 1st was 3-hour read and 2nd a 5-hour one. While it's possible to skip through the story by pressing CTRL for achievements
recommended: I can recommend reading through the story: it's an emotional and even revealing experience to issues and thoughts of people suffering from difficult diseases. As such
hoursPlayed: it provokes one to think about life perhaps from a new perspective. To me
voteText: that makes it worthwhile a read."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I actually never heard of this Visual novel before i saw it on steam; I saw it on Greenlight, and I voted for it (mainly because I am a HUGE visual novel fan; even to the point of adding Katawa Shoujo to my non-steam steam games). I saw it finally was released and decided to download it immediately. I then sat down and beat the 1st 'side'; and decided to write my review (also apologies if it is vague, I wanted to avoid spoilers, and this is my first in depth review I wrote).

This visual novel is quite amazing in my opinion; it really brought emotion out of me, something most movies, games, and books cannot do (although there have been one or two games and books, and a handful of movies).

There aren't too many images used, but what images are used are amazing looking, and are very beautiful. The dialog is very descriptive, and it is translated amazingly.

The music score/soundtrack to this game is just as amazing as the rest of this visual novel; it fits in perfectly, and both sets and amplifies the mood, making the scenes much more powerful. (The soundtrack is available for purchase, and i recomend picking it up if you have the money)

The impact this game left on me is strong, I even cried at the end [I know; I’m a dork ha-ha] because of its depressing... but strangely satisfying and even somewhat happy ending (I know this seems like a contradicting statement; but it will make sense when you beat it).

I whole-heartedly recommend this to anyone who enjoys visual novels, great stories, or emotionally charged entertainment; best of all is that this amazing experience is free. I give narcissu a 10/10!!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNarcissu is a sad, haunting tale accompanied by beautiful artwork and music, and it’s a good example of a literary form of the visual novel. It requires a little patience from the reader, but it’ll make you think, and unless you’re carved out of stone, it’ll make you feel, too. You may feel sad, you may feel confused, you may even feel outraged, but your emotions will be stirred, and that was the author’s sole intention. It’s a road trip worth taking.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A true-to-life visual novel simulating real-life crisis, depression, torment, and sadness.  Told in 2 parts, Narcissu 1st and Narcissu 2nd (which actually narrates the events that occurred before Narcissu 1st) both bring out the feels in you.  You will not only come to feel that you are just someone who is filled with anguis, pain, and hopelessness after being diagnosed with life-ending disease but worse than that is experiencing the loss of the love and acknowledgement of your very existence as a homo-sapien by the people who are very close to you or those that share a special bond with you.

You may choose from many translations and having the characters be either voiced or unvoiced which is very nice.  The art style is very minimalistic but is quite effective in portraying the setting and conveying the concurrent mood to the reader.  The audio tracks are also excellent and noticeably alters the ambient setting in a dynamic fashion to which later events may be foreshadowed when combined with powerful imagery.  Both novels are broken up into chapters which also make it very easy to locate and resume from the last checkpoint; and not mentioning a save function that allows continuation from any point in a chapter.  The cream of the crop in terms of enriching user experience, in this review at least, is having the ability to auto-advance text with no manual mouse-clicking necessary.

All-in-all you can be sure to possibly shed a few tears along the way--so prepare some cleanex before you dive in. Even if you arent easily perturbed, emotionally-wise, you can still be surprised by how the novel project its powerful elements upon you to a resounding degree which easily invoke feelings of sentiment for the character.  it is, in essence, very touching text-wrapped journey that recounts the tale of a girl who is passionate about cars and her tireless endeavours in seeking true freedom and the gift of life.

reviewText: I haven't finished 2nd yet, but Narcissu 1st made me cry at the end (in a good way)! reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Narcissu games are short, simple and bittersweet tragedies. Even though the characters are simple, they are consistently believable and interesting enough to make you care about them. The Plot tends to air somewhat on the predictable side but most of the little events in the middle nonetheless remain interesting. Since music is part of the atmosphere, and atmosphere is undoubtedly of utmost importance in a visual novel that aims to be emotionally gripping, the soundtrack deserves a great amount of praise.

The Highlights:
Music:  Beautifully melancholic, fitting
Art:  simple, yet evocative
Plot:  Simple, predictable, yet properly detailed
Ending:  Powerful

I also recommend the 3rd Narcissu game to all the people who like the first two games

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A free visual novel. Narcissu has no real desicion points and mostly shows only pictures of the scenery in this visual novel, but I have personally taken a liking to the soundtracks in this game.
As for the story, it's certainly capable of making you feel something for these characters as they carry on throughout the last days of their lives in Narcissu 1st. Narcissu 2nd side may not be -as- depressing as the first, but still delivers the feels every now and then~
If you're mostly interested in the story, capable of dealing with tearing up once in awhile, and fine with a visual novel that isn't always going to provide top-knotch visuals around every single corner, I certainly recommend this free visual novel game.
It's certainly a try if you like decent stories.

reviewText:
First thing you need to know is..

This is NOT a game.  There are visual novel that have game choices and etc and that would be a choice and decision game...

This is not NOT a game. It doesn't have choices and the only thing you need to do is once a chapter end click the next chapter and you can press space to speed things up.

That being said..
This is FREE.
This is a beautiful book with a wonderfully touching story.
This Game" have achievements.

Despite being a girlish book it have some nice plots and fun to read.
I enjoyed both 1 & 2.

IF you bored from gaming want sometime off reading book go for this one.. Again it's free.

IF you just want boost your achievement ratio.
Turn this game on. Change speed to auto-read to high.
Start this game "unvoiced" then press "A" to start auto-read.
Watch some TV with this game on. Click A every once a while at stuck point or mouse click to chapter change.
Once your unvoiced achievement Pops just go to the menu and this time select "Voiced" then click last chapter.
Keep mouse clicking or space clicking until achievement.
Move to second book. Do the same thing.
Move to Extra ending. Do the same thing.
You just got another 100% game...

For review wise..
1/10 as A game.. 7/10 as a Book."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a heartbreaking visual novel directly shipped from Japan. The story itself will make your soul shatter into a thousand pieces, the soundtrack is bound to stay in your head for at least a million years and you will never forget the names of Setsumi & Himeko.

I don't want to spoil anything, so I just state some things I liked and some that were not that good.

Pro:
★ pricetag: none
★ optional Japanese voice-acting done by real actors
★ 10-12 hrs of gameplay
★ 26 different songs
★ rare but beautiful artworks
★ notes from the author & the translators
★ optional purchase of the OST as an DLC (MP3 & FLAC)
★ autoplay mode to just sit back and enjoy

Cons:
☆ menus a bit chaotic
☆ no artwork gallery
☆ 4:3 aspect ratio only
☆ background music sometimes too loud to clearly understand the voice-acting

The original visual novels are from 2005 and 2007, so don't be too strict on the technical level. Just enjoy it the way it is.

reviewText:
*Updated for Fixed Achievements.*

Wow, just where the hell do I even begin with this one? I have to put two novels under retrospect this time around, so here I go, I guess.

Narcissu 1st & 2nd are a pair of novels centering around individuals cursed with the life of disease with their stories opaque with sensitive subjects such as solitude, misery, and death. It is apparent that these games are rather low budget but such qualities are negligible upon considering the heart that was applied ever so sincerely in every part about it. Again, these are two novels you're getting here (for free, too), ergo the review is divided into two, for each of the games/novels.

--Narcissu--

The first Narcissu title follows a nameless protagonist that just recently became admitted to his hospital's 7th floor after being a normal patient for a while. His patient bracelet shifts to a white color as he is informed that no further treatment can be provided for his illness, thus his transfer after the recognition of limited time left in his life. There, he meets the silent, 22 year-old woman named Setsumi (severely underdevloped. Like, loli physique, so just call her a girl, really) and seeing how he is a resident of the top floor, she informs him about the fate of dying soon after 3 temporary discharges. After gazing at the lounge's television with this girl for a considerable amount of time, both decide that they both despise the atmospheres of their home and the hospital, and the protagonist then, simply put, steals his dad's silver coupe. Without a destination, they commence their 15 day travels with nothing other than a couple thousand yen, a driver's license, and pajamas. A little nitpick I had with all this is that it is never, not even in the second game, disclosed what exact illness these two might be suffering from, but after everything's all said and done it won't really matter.

Unnecessary synopsis over, we can now proceed to the core of this game, which is the characters themselves. While both Setsumi and the protagonist themselves are not particularly" intriguing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu is one of the best Visual Novels I've ever played, which is odd because it lacks a staple feature of the genre in having no choices.Reading the author's notes he states that he wanted this VN to flow like a movie and have good pacing which really adds to it more than it takes away. The story has more meaning behind it than just tear-jerking/FEELS, and the minimalistic art makes you feel like your a bystander listening in instead of looking at talking heads for hours. After playing both Narcissu 1 and 2, I feel that 1 has a better story and has a stronger experience behind it, but 2 is better produced and has a sadder story. Narcissu 2nd definitely makes you feel for Setsumi more in part 1, and gives you some insight into how she feels.

I think I should mention that the author states in the notes he would like people to play 2nd before 1st because it's the chronological order. I personally played 1st before 2nd because I played 1st when it was first translated by insani a few years ago. But it definitely would probably be a more powerful experience if you played 2nd before 1st, knowing what happens kind of gave me a weird feeling, it's hard to explain, but I think it would make the 1st game an even greater experience if you had the build up of 2nd still in your mind.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu is a great VN (visual novel) and well if you haven't tried it yet you really owe it to yourself to try this, as it is a very emotional experience, it has a great sound track and it is short and free so you might aswell just download it now as your not paying anything to try.

Narcissu is a pretty depressing VN as it's about terminally ill people, who are going to die soon the story takes you through the hardships and isololation their illnes causes them. So be WARNED after reading this it will be pretty difficult to be happy for a while but it's good that this VN gets you emotionalally invested in the characters. The concept and writing was good and I did enjoy the characters aswell, but I want to specifically mention the sound track. It was really well done and helped enhance pretty much every scene, it not only suited the scenes, but it enhanced them aswell, when something emotional was happening, I was sad due to what was happening but the sound track really gave everything an extra kick, it was definitely well done.

What might put somepeople of is that this is a novel meaning you have hardly any interaction, think of it as a book with sound and visuals as a aid, as all you will do is click or  nothing at all if you set it to auto scroll, so whilst it has a good story, you should be warned this isn't really like a game this is more like a novel as it has no gameplay what so ever (No choices in this VN either).

However I will still recommend this, the story is good, the characters are strong and I don't think I have anything else on my Steam Library which has made me feel as much for the characters as this VN does. The topics it explores is heavy but I felt that this was an interesting experience putting myself in the shows of somebody who doesn't have much time, did also get me to reflect on what my reaction would be to this situation and I do feel like I have gained something just by exploring this topic.
Its only a few hours long, its pretty well done, it is also free, I don't think there is a reason for you to not at least try it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Another brilliant Visual Novel with touching, well written story. Narcissu shows that even text can convey the deepest of the emotion.

To play the 'game', you need to sit back, relax, click thru the dialogues slowly and enjoy it. Just don't forget to occassionally save so you won't bang your head against the wall if your machine magically crashes and you need to restart the story all over again.

Replayability is zero. Once you finish once, that's all you need to do. Except if you want to recall the story later.

As an Early Access, Narcissu is pretty much done and polished - except for blank so-called Achievements - and most importantly it's completely translated into English. I'm surprised they didn't charge a dime for this on Steam.

The only purchasable DLC here is OSTs. While I don't own the DLC myself, it's been said that the quality of the OSTs are FLAC, pretty much what we expect nowadays (who likes lossy MP3s now?). Even so, I can vet for the quality of the OSTs in-game, it's very memorable and deep, perfectly blend into the story and I can fully recommend this set for your listening pleasure.

All in all, it's a free stuff with great presentation and story that you can finish in one sitting (at least for each part). Well worth your time. 10/10.

reviewText:
Absolutely brilliant. Two heart touching stories very well attached with an amazing narrative, simply but effective artwork and a nice soundtrack. Dubbing is sensational, even in japanese or whatever, it makes you to know how they felt in every conversation.

Worth reading. The first one is a main story about Setsumi and the second one is the prequel of the first one but with another character, Himeko... longer and with many more details that explain to the reader why Setsumi behaves in that way.

No choices, even a game, nor the typical an audiovisual novel, is just like a book so there is nothing to do except read, listen and feel.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Spoilers ahead)

Narcissu is an unavoidable story. It's the only way it could ever happen. But this isn't enough. What I always wanted to say is, Setsumi wouldn't have it another way. She would travel with someone to a place where there are Narcissus and she would kill herself, drowning in the sea.

But this isn't (only) because she wanted so. She knew every escape route, she had saved money, she specifically stated she didn't want to die neither at home nor at the hospital. What's the protagonist's role, then, since he's but a witness in all this process?

This is what I couldn't decipher. True, Setsumi can't drive, but as aforementioned, she could very well take the train. She knew where she wanted to go, she knew how she wanted to die. Yet, the story was written in such a way that you just had to be there.

Both you and the protagonist know or at least have a clue that she's coaxing you into taking her to her desired place with all her not particularly..." catch phrase instances. There's a dissonance here too

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Naruissu is a visual novel that tells a story in both an interactive and emotional way. This story forces the feelings of its characters in a way that you can connect with by putting you in the middle of the action (like most visual novels do). Narcissu 1st is absoluetly worth reading. You bond with a girl named Setsumi. First meeting her at a hospital, then soon you're on a wild adventure throughout Japan. Setsumi can be described in one word, tsundere (Cold on the outside, THE FEELS ON THE INSIDE). As you prgress in the story, she slowly opens up to you. In the end, you are left with feelings of happiness, sadness and longing for more. Narcissu 2nd is the prequel to Narcissu 1st (yeah oddly enough). This story is about friendship, hardship and loss. Our beloved Setsumi has only begun to experience her life in the hospital. There she meets the prequel's other protagonist, Himeko. Narcissu 2nd is more to clarify Narcissu 1st and is not at all needed to be played first to enjoy Narcissu 1st.

tl;dr:
-Narcissu 1st is an AMAZING visual novel filled with emotions that you are looking for if you want to cry.
-Narcissu 2nd is a prequel to clarify questions in Narcissu 1st. This does not need to be played first to enjoy Narcissu 1st.
Criticism (not like I'm a visual novel critic):
-I reaaaaally wish they put actions you can choose from which would effect the outcome of the story.
-Why is there not more of these types of VN on steam?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As this was only one of my first few visual novels I don't have much experience to be able to compare it to much else, however, I really enjoyed the Narcissu 1st game. I haven't begun the 2nd one yet but I would like to at one point. I just knocked out the 1st in almost a single sitting so it took a while. :P I will note that the achievement system seems to be broken. I completed Narcissu 1st, the voiced version, and did not receive the achievement for it. That aside it was a decent story and I enjoyed it. It definitely tugged at my heartstrings a few times and made me want to cry a few times as well. If you have never played a visual novel or have only played a few, as I have, it will take a little while to get into it but don't give up! The story does improve with time. :3 ***SPOILER ALERT: I wish that the ending was different, though and instead he pulled her away... :< *sadface****

UPDATE: I have just completed Narcissu 2nd and I feel as though the story was an improvement on the 1st. I feel as though I felt more emotion and it was nice to get a backstory on Setsumi! I however ***SPOILER ALERT: am a bit disturbed by the fact that suicide seems to be so nonchalant in these games. It is a very serious matter and I don't think this should be taken at all lightly. There were also sacrilegious messages but if you are able to ignore that the story is absolutely emotional and you really start feeling close to the characters... or at least I seemed to. :)***

I have also heard about a Narcissu 3rd in Japan so perhaps it will be translated in the future and brought here? Until then I definitely enjoyed these games. Remember they do go somewhat slow at first if you aren't used to games like this but if you can bear with it the story is pretty good! Definitely something to play if you like emotional stories. But be warned that there is sacrilege so if you can put that past you and just focus on the story it is an enjoyable story overall but also highly depressing! Have tissues ready!!! XD
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd are two short indie visual novels about residents of the 7th floor of an hospital. However, those residents aren't only sick; they cannot be cured, and so they wait for death to take them.

With such a premise, you can easily tell the story will make you shed some tears, and trust me it will. It is a sad, but incredibly beautiful, journey, which makes me recommend it wholeheartedly. Also, while there aren't that many songs in the soundtrack, they all are beautiful and really add to the atmosphere and emotions of the story.

On a more technical standpoint, both Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd are quite short VNs (completed both aswell as the epilogue in 9.3 hours) in which there aren't any choices to make. Some might say this lack of any gameplay mechanics is a bad thing, but in my opinion it allows you to stay focused, if not immerged, in the story.

The only things I might complain about would be the few mistakes in the text, the sometimes confusing syntax (though I understand the goal of the translators, as described in the translators' notes), and the rather small pictures and text-box.

All in all, Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd are really worth the time reading in my opinion, even more so considering they are free. Give them a try, you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ALL ABOARD THE FEELS TRAIN!!
Without further ado let's start:

Story - You ''play'' an unnamed 20 year old man, suffering from an terminal illness called lung carcinoma who has been hospitalized and will die because of that illness, they place him in a wing called 7F where he meets a  young woman named Setsumi, 22 years of age. she has a body physique like a child and has a quiet personality. The story properly begins when the protagonists father visits his son in the hospital and leaves his car keys on a table, protagonist takes them and invites Setsumi to go along with him. The two escape the hospital and begin a roadtrip with seemingly no end goal.

Gameplay - The game is a visual novel with little to no interaction if you have autoscroll on the text, so it isn't a ''game'' excactly.

Voice acting and presentation - The ''game'' has very little of the characters and is compromised of a textwindow and a narrow movielike image, the voiceacting is completely optional but i recommend turning it on with autoplay enabled so you don't accidentally skip any speech.

Overall the visual novel is touching and has a very sad undertone driven by the fate of the main characters (incurable illness) so they both know they will die soon or sooner and the novel leaves a bittersweet taste of tears afterwards so i would conclude this with a rating for anyone who loves sad stories of visual novels definetly a 8/10 (would feel again) but for any other person do not expect too much.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt is difficult to write a review for Narcissu 1& 2 as it is not a game nor is it completely a visual novel with branching choices; it is more so what people call a “kinetic novel”.  While the player has little control over what is happening on the screen, as they can only move forward with the plot, I however have never been more engrossed into a story on screen.  Everything from the minimal visuals and the hauntingly memorable soundtrack all helps the player in being attached to this depressingly beautiful plot full of heartache, death, meaning, and life.  I encourage everyone to try this out; I strongly believe anyone who experiences this VN will come out as a better person with a new appreciation for life.  Best of all, it is free.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter I finished this game, water started slowly seeping out of my eyes. I didn't know what was happening, a game had never made me feel this way before. I could feel my vision blur with water blocking my line of sight. My body mass slowly became lighter as the floor beneath me became more damp, water pooling beneath me. My mouth felt dry and my stomach felt empty, I quickly realized that all of the liquid inside of my body was being sucked out of my body and pouring out of my eyelids. My chair starting floating in the small lake that had formed in my room. There was no end in sight. The house had to be drained and dry cleaned four times to get rid of all the water. Don't read this visual novel.

reviewText:
I came into this game knowing that it was about sick characters and I left caring about those sick characters. It is definitely worth a play through. The 2nd one was the better one and the only I actually cried on. The flow and the characters of that one really gets you. It's hard not to get attached to the characters. The 1st one wass alright, just not as emotionally tugging as the 2nd. It only really followed two characters and their really long car ride.

The images of the game are beautiful, no doubt about that. Although there was at least one that struck me as strange. I'm not sure if describing it would be spoilers, but for someone who just got out of a long hospital stay, their face would not look like that when they get on the bar. Unless she had magic anime muscles, which might explain everything. Just a minor detail though, the art isn't at all bad! (They all look like children too, even the adults. But again, minor detail.)

The music was just great. It really fits with the situations and gives you the feel of this being their moment. I don't know how to describe it, actually. Just know that if I had rewards to give out for best music in visual novels, this game would get all of them.

It has voice acting, if that's what you're into. But I honestly just rushed through that part and played through it silent twice to get the achievements. To me, since i played it silent the first time around, all the characters had their own voice inside my head. The actual voices aren't bad though.

Do I recommend this? Heck yes. Definitely. Play it now.

Early Access Review

Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a Japanese visual novel developed by stage-nana and written originally in Japanese by Tomo Kataoka. This VN tells the story about the residence of 7th floor Setsumi Sakura and her experience during the last moment of her life.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I played this a while ago, when it wasn't available on Steam.

I'm going to say it now. Most people won't like this, as you have to read and have patience. It's not an action game, it's not even a game, as such. It's a  VISUAL NOVEL.  I have played quite a few of these, and fell in love a year or so ago. Sadly, they never hit the Western audience, generally being produced by Japanese developers, in Japan, in Japanese. Visual novels are what they say they are -- books that you can see. It is a book. That's it. But - as with books - it's the story that grabs you, and I must say, this had a pretty damn good story. If you are a person that likes to read -- go ahead. If you are a person that likes to be gripped by a devastating story -- go ahead. If you are a person that likes to cry your heart out cry manly tears at the end of the story, at the end of the road. Go. Go and read this. I can't express it enough, I thought I had no soul left after my previous visual novel. It turned out I did.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is an amazing game. I have played many Japanese Galgames and this game brings me the first feeling of a true situation: the meaning of the death and life. This is amazing, in my opinion, galgame is just a type of game that meet a girl and have a nice love story. However this game shows me another spirit, I feel very sad when I knew the girl's death but after that I still thinking. The girl isn't happy when she alive and the only thing she want in this hopeless world is just a scene of flowers.When she really came to there, I think she has already gain the value of her life though it is a very short and painful life. At last she committed suicide but I think she must do this with a bright smile. So this is a wonderful meaning game. If you like a story with the meaning of life, if you are a painful and hopeless patient like the girl, or if you want to commit suicide, I strongly recommend you to play this game. This game will help you find the meaning of your life and help you to gain your own value of your life. Before you die, why not play this game first and find something that can really move you?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu is a VN that lacks the typical VN feeling of agency, the feeling of that you are making your own decisicion or dialogue choices.what I mean by lacking is that This game has none of those, oh no.This VN is literaly a VN, a Visual Novel.With no interactions and no branching storyline whatsoever, however.The game provides a strong narative that immerses you with the characters.With death as a theme and a canvas for the narative, death is a inevitable end and This VN doesnt contain any romance.Which is not this VN is about, this VN is about death and of one's experience before their demise.

I recommend this game for people who wants a good and solid story of death told in a form of a VN.
I dont recommend this game for people who wants agency and romance in their VNs ,because there is none.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Fun                                                                      AESTHETIC:
MEMORABILITY:                                              WORTH: Free!

PROS:  Different subtitle sets are available. The environment is very pretty. For taking place mostly inside a car, Narcissu 1 is engaging. Great soundtrack. Surprisingly Fulfilling for a Free to play game! Several key/mouse options to click to progress, allowing you to alternate how you're positioned while reading.

CONS: All of the game's visuals are trapped in an uncomfortable little letterbox. This is a unique stylization, but a little annoying. There are no character sprites, you see the female lead perhaps 4 times total in the first game. At times, it is nauseatingly melancholy. Voice option is not very good. I found the sequel to be weak and feel that it drones on aimlessly.

OVERALL: There is absolutely no interaction in this VN, but it's still a nice little ride. I liked it, but you may not; If you're looking for a peaceful, satisfying read with a nice conclusion then this is a great F2P story.

SCORE: 6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First, don't expect this to be a game. There's no interaction, no choices to make, nothing to do except read and press the space bar to progress through the story.

Saying that, this is a really good visual novel. There are two stories. The first takes places after the second. If you want to do them chronologically, start with the second then the first. However, in my opinion, the stories work better if you go through them the other way.

It needs to be said that there's a trigger warning for suicide in these stories. So if that bothers you, you may want to pass this over. If not, I highly recommend downloading and completing both stories.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a visual novel, Narcissu is pretty short, but definitely worth downloading. It offers an intruiging look at life, death, and terminal illness, with a gorgeous soundtrack and interesting characters to go along with it. My only gripe with it was the narrow screen, which may have just been an aesthetic choice on the designer's part.

If you don't like reading, I cannot recommend this game to you, as it has you read a lot of dialogue and monologues. If you do like reading, however, and don't mind that you'll be doing nothing but clicking to advance to the next piece of dialogue, this might be a great entry point to the world of visual novels.

reviewText: like the walking dead but with feels 10/10\n\nIn all seriousness though, even though this was short (2 hours for me to read both parts) the OST alone made up for it. The only major flaw is that the narrator sometimes switches without telling you (which shouldn't be a big deal if you're using the voiced, but I played the unvoiced version). While Narcissu 1 was a pretty solid tale of its own accord, Narcissu 2 drove it home even further and made it that more memorable. Most games I spend under 5 hours on I end up not really liking and dropping, as they fail to have an impact on me. Narcissu is an exception: for a short VN, it packs quite a punch, and I'd recommend it to anyone who hasn't had their daily dose of feels.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAfter some time, I managed to finish this visual novel. When I first started reading it I was surprised by the complete lack of choices, since most other visual novels are a 'choose your own adventure' variant. This isn't necessarily bad, but I like to be in control of the main character, even if it's slight. This, naturally also leaves only one route to follow, and one possible ending. This makes replayability.... slim, as well as shorten the novels length. However, the story you do get is pretty interesting, and toys with your emotions pretty well, regardless of the fact that the first novel has no character development, and the protagonist just kind of does things. Setsumi, the protagonists 'friend', is dull and boring. She is overly intelligent with no explanations as to how she knows anything considering she's spent most of her time in the hospital. Side 2nd goes into some detail as to why she knows these things, and is in my opinion the better of the 2 novels. We learn more about Setsumi, and her past, as the story is told primarily from her point of view. Side 2nd was longer, and had a more satisfying end, and there was some character development with the main characters. The soundtrack is.... decent, it does the job, but there weren't any notable tracks that I particularly liked, and it didn't transition very well between scenes. It's nothing special. The voice acting was pretty good for the most part, particularly for setsumis character in the first novel. The same voice actor is in side 2nd as setsumi, but she sounded just as depressed as she is in the first novel, which doesn't make sense considering she still had some hope at this point in the timeline. The other female protagonist in side 2nd is great, she sounds very cheerful, and knew how to be fun, and serious when necessary. None of the other voice actors stood out, as they had few lines. If you're looking for a good read, I would recommend this, but don't expect anything too special.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Do you like sad music , sad sounding people that speak japanese with english subs then this game about 2 people ( Nameless Male ) and the other setsumi the main female character.

Story 8/10

The story behind this game is about a girl named setsumi  has an illness they never put a name on  she lived normal her entier life still she was in middle school then she is hospitalized and her friend come to her every day at the hospital  and give her good wish cards , untill she keeps getting hospitalized that she becomes a fragment in everyones mind. Those people she called friends are now just strangers  to her she keeps doing the same  cycle over and over  < Hospital < Stay for Weeks < Clinic < Hospital > And it goes on and on.

Protaginist (Nameless Male )

This Male you meet in the first chapter of the first game tells you that he has the same illness as the setsumi  and  is in the same cycle  as her and then he ends up on the 7th floor  with this girl setsumi  on his second  day there he sees her in the longue starring blankly  at the TV nothing interesting playing.



Sound Track 9/10

The sound track for this VN is just beautiful and has lots of  sad piano notes that add to the emotional break down to the characters that they have later in the story , like the first sound track you hear is  quite sadistic sounds but also kind of soothing to your ears cause of the fluid sound going with the piano it adds lots of emotion to the game as the characters are pretty dull cause of they're sad looking and bery depressed looking and sounds ( If you do voice over ) and then when they leave they kinda brighten not that much but it makes the story a littleless sad until , you get farther in the story and do the second game but the sound track gets better and worse has it's ups and downs everywhere.


My Verdict

My verdict in total  is a  9.1 as the sound track and story went together   so well in my opinion the characters  never had many dull points just a  few drops here or there that didn't make much  of a difference to me , the story/plot was amazing to my taste of story as i  have an attraction to sad and depression stories and situations , as well as games of sadness and All those kind of things. I recommend playing this VN it opens a lot of ideas up to simple minded people aswell as some amazing ideas for sad stories of death or relationships or something of that matter.


9/11 is my ACTUAL final verdict Hue Hue Hue

reviewText:
Overview:This is a visual novel where there will be images associated with words. It's just like kindergarten story time~! The story however takes on a bit more grim setting than your usual happy endings.

The Story:       You were like any other child until you were diagnosed with a terminal illness at five years of age. In & out of hospitals since getting sick you've lost contact with your childhood friends and disassociated yourself from life as an complacent observer living life day by day. After the hospital has done everything they can for you they send you to a floor away from the daily bustle of other coming & going patients. Going to the morbid, but supposedly happy recreational room on the floor you meet another patient. You're informed of the rule of the floor by another terminal patient of how you will die and how you must inform others of the rule when they arrive just like you. Dissatisfied of how you will die without experiencing life you finally decide to runaway taking your fellow patient with you, but unfortunately harsh reality sets in as your friend eventually succumbs to...

2nd Narcissu:  I can only imagine it's among the same setting as the 1st whereas there will be a pair of friends and a ******. Might be wrong, so find out for yourself.

I will leave the rest for you to discover if you're interested.

Achievement Hunters:

Press Ctrl to skip through story.

1st Narcissu:
Prologue + 8 Chapters
2nd Narcissu:
Prologue + 19 Chapters

It will take you approximately 30min[Not Skipping] to finish each storyline once then all you have to do to unlock the unvoiced achievement is to run through the last chapter.

The hidden achievement is the Epilogue in the start menu. Not sure if voiced, or unvoiced matters.

reviewText: Amazing. Let's just cut to the chase here... These VNs are ROUGH. Very well done, beautiful, engaging, and tasteful, but it's a tough one. After unlocking the dev's Notes, you know these weren't meant to be tear-jerkers
date: but I just about had a fit after 1st.\n\nIf you have ever wondered about the world of chronic/terminal illness and the associated psychological warfare that accompany the regular symptoms, this is almost a case study. This game masterfully illustrates the inner workings of the minds of those essentially given a diagnosis of IDK
recommended: good luck to you." It's about grief
hoursPlayed: guilt
voteText: and grace.\n\nI appreciate the focus on the deeper questions people given a finite timeline to work with have to answer. Sometimes it's not just about depression or self-blame. Rather
helpfulPercent: it can be about feeling objectified and out of control
votesHelpful: coupled with a deeply profound view on the long-term effects interactions will have on anyone involved in the health/well-being process.\n\nFocusing on how people in these positions can and will think about how to execute the "end-game" was extremely welcoming and refreshing to see explored
votesTotal: When the body fails and is beyond personal control
votesFunny: most people don't know the internal struggle that ensues in trying to be resolve the situation and re-align the bodyand mind in the most peaceful way possible.\n\nI unintentionally played the game 1st and 2nd
commentsCount: without knowing the developer wanted it to be played in reverse. However
column16: I enjoyed the juxtaposition of the stories
column17: and the conclusions that can be drawn by revisiting the first part after completing the second are very eye-opeing. I was happy that the subject of religion and morality was brought up in the 2nd
column18: because it is a deep and frustrating struggle that people really wrestle with in the medical world (and will continue to do so).\n\nOverall
column20: especially if you or someone you know is going through a similar fight."

reviewText: like the walking dead but with feels 10/10\n\nIn all seriousness though, even though this was short (2 hours for me to read both parts) the OST alone made up for it. The only major flaw is that the narrator sometimes switches without telling you (which shouldn't be a big deal if you're using the voiced, but I played the unvoiced version). While Narcissu 1 was a pretty solid tale of its own accord, Narcissu 2 drove it home even further and made it that more memorable. Most games I spend under 5 hours on I end up not really liking and dropping, as they fail to have an impact on me. Narcissu is an exception: for a short VN, it packs quite a punch, and I'd recommend it to anyone who hasn't had their daily dose of feels.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a visual novel, Narcissu is pretty short, but definitely worth downloading. It offers an intruiging look at life, death, and terminal illness, with a gorgeous soundtrack and interesting characters to go along with it. My only gripe with it was the narrow screen, which may have just been an aesthetic choice on the designer's part.

If you don't like reading, I cannot recommend this game to you, as it has you read a lot of dialogue and monologues. If you do like reading, however, and don't mind that you'll be doing nothing but clicking to advance to the next piece of dialogue, this might be a great entry point to the world of visual novels.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Background: As part of the Sekai Project, Narcissu 1st & 2nd is a Japanese Visual Novel developed by stage-nana which is originally written by Tomo Kataoka. Many people were involved, to know more download the game and read the notes. This visual novel is a story with Setsumi Sakura, a character, playing as the main role. Throughout the story will be the experiences she has during her last moments living.

Be Advised, this Visual Novel's level of feels may or may not desecrate your feels gauge meter. Experiences of this Visual Novel may differ from person to person.

Personally I would like to say this is a masterpiece not because of the feelings you get but a masterpiece in because it conveys its message well. The point is, Tomo Kataoka's message and story IS well conveyed, the storytellers voice is heard.

If Narcissu 3rd ever comes on Steam. I'm buying it immediately!

Not really fond of the art style, but the story more than makes up for it. Would  NOT  recommend to anyone suffering from depression, though.

reviewText:
Free to play japanese Visual Novels.  Two very sad and long stories.   Spacebar to move through it.  No decisions.  Subject matter might not be good for little kids.
Has nice background music, sound effects and voiceovers, has nice artwork, has steam achievements for reaching the end of stories.  On the second runthrough, you can start a new story, of the other version and pick the last chapter to get the other achievement.

The Extras is the Sound mode, pick through the soundtrack.

If you like novels, give this a try.

reviewText:
Narcissu 1:

I thought I was prepared to read this, but nothing can prepare you for this.

The story is about two sick patients in a hospital who have embraced their inevitable deaths. One day they both have a chance to escape the monotony of the life that they had forced apon them when they were young. Where will they go with no destination? What will they do knowing nothing but the life of a patient in a hospital ward?

There is no greater plot, there is no romance, and the relationship between the two main characters could hardly even be described as friendly, but the coldness of the cast and simple story both play very important roles in tying the incredible atmosphere of the VN together.

The game actually comes with two translations one of which focused on retaining the original script's phrasing (resulting in some rather poor grammar at times) while the second translation focused more on  shapng the script into something closer to what a native english speaker would have written. Both read surprisingly different, and neither is the wrong choice.

9/10 would piece together my heart again

reviewText:
If you haven't already gone through this visual novel, please do so. It may be free but it's most definitly worth your time.
And please, start with the 2nd Narcissu first. It definitly offers more of a payoff that way, and the notes do state that that is the preferred way of reading it.

But anyway, my review.
I wasn't ready for the amount of feels I was going to get from a free visual novel. I didn't expect much, ya know? But boy, was I plesantly surprised. Though, I use plesant in a weird way: I had a great time wiping away my tears, I guess.

There were issues, yes. The panel changing was a little odd sometimes. There were spelling errors drizzled about. I even had two clicks that were just odd symbols for who knows why. But there are easly looked over if you just skim like I did.

Narcissu 1st was definitly the odd ball for me. There were questionable actions taken by the characters and some things I felt were not well explained, but the ending was so worth the journey there and most everything that was confusing was explained in the 2nd part. But as I said in the very beginning, if you start with the 2nd it should make more sense.

I don't have much else to say, other than the fact that you /need/ to play this game if you like visual novels. Take it with a grain of salt because it's a totally free experiance, but it's an experiance you don't want to miss.
Oh, and don't forget to pass on the rules. It's a legacy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu (1st and 2nd) is a slightly sad, yet somewhat cute story that takes a look at patients of a hospital (hospice) who don't have a long time left to live. I definitely lean more towards the thumbs up" button than to not recommend it. The game (read: visual novel) have that amateurish feel to it. It doesn't affect the game negatively. Perhaps more the opposite - like comparing a hand-made product to a mass produced one. The story holds up quite well and the background music is solid work that adds to the immersion. I would have liked a bit more depression to it for that extra impact. But that's just my personal love for depressing stories. The ending was quite satisfying.

By all means
date: give it a go when you are bored or feel like trying out some non-interactive visual novel. It's a free title. You'll only lose time
recommended: but hopefully gain something worth it to think about.\n\nEDIT: Oh yeah. The artwork is decent especially in the 2nd title. Scarce in quantity but it leaves more for your imagination. Manga/anime haters though: Don't bother. This is not for you."
