reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFew novels of any sort are dedicated to chronic or terminal illness, especially when they afflict the young.  I'm as close to an expert as one can be on this subject and still be living.  I survived a nearly fatal heart issue at age 18 and had two open heart surgeries.  I also volunteered in the child life department (duties very similar to the helper" in this story -- basically being a supportive friend) for several years at a children's hospital on the acute care floor
date: the hem/onc floor and the NICU.\n\nThat said
recommended: I was really intrigued by this and hoping to find something that spoke to the experiences I have shared with children who I have worked with who are terminally ill and the friends I have made in support groups who have struggled with giant chest scars in their teens
hoursPlayed: coping with confronting death while your college friends are out partying
voteText: learning to change your IV bags while your bff is talking about her favorite clothes
helpfulPercent: and generally losing your supposed best years of your life.\n\nI was ideally hoping for something I could pass on to my friends who have dealt with these same issues or my family who truly cannot fathom what that kind of life experience does to an 18-23 year old.  Unfortunately
votesHelpful: I can't say that this really deals with many of the issues we face.  I believe that there are some really important points it manages to pick up on briefly that healthy individuals may not have ever considered: the families that abandon children in hospitals because it's too much to bear
votesTotal: the isolation of the young in a landscape of the dying elderly
votesFunny: the alienation one feels from her own body -- particularly because of scarring or the presentation of what is considered acceptable by the fashion industry.\n\nHowever
commentsCount: I did think this could have used some editing and likely some research into specific illnesses as well.  Portraying nebulous illnesses
column16: sternotomy scars and "medications" didn't really impact me when that kind of stuff becomes your daily bag in reality.  I also thought some of the character switches were clumsy at times
column17: though the pay-offs at times when things came full circle was cute.  All in all
column18: though
column19: I was left feeling like this did not ring true to the experiences I knew of we young folk trapped in hospitals -- though it was a valiant attempt and some people might enjoy it.  I wouldn't recommend it to my friends or families to learn more about our experiences
column20: and I wouldn't recommend it to my peers as an introspective dip into our pasts.\n\nI think my largest problem was the complete absence of the illness
column21: its accoutrements and its physical impacts from these characters despite their being apparently near death.  I get that this isn't a documentary
column26: and being sliced and diced is such a huge part of what one has to process and your identity while your best friends are just like
column27: "Man.  Essays suck."  The fact that the characters only deal with half of dying is a hard thing for me to let go of
column28: especially when the characters just generally seem to be withering away from a general 19th c malaise.\n\nBarely recommended as a fair attempt to portray a complex subject on which the authors did not have a clear grasp.  Glad someone tackled it

reviewText:
Excellent story with decent soundtracks.

SPOILER ALERT

This game is a must play for visual novel gamers because of its deep plot about a girl suffering from cancer. Our story starts with a protagonist, a young man who is admitted to a hospital with lung carcinoma. He eventually meets another girl who has the same diagnosis as him. She indicates that they are slowly dying and the cancer may returns after therapy. She is in her final stage of cancer as she may pass away at any moment. As the cancer progresses, they will eventually die at the seventh floor of the hosptial at the palliative unit, or at home with family. The girl calmly expresses that she doesn't want to die at the hospital nor home. She wants to escape and asks the protagonist to come along her. That's her final wish... to die alone without her family and friends... because they are the ones that suffer more.

reviewText: This was a wonderful experience. The story is well-written, and honestly, it prompted me to reflect on the value and shortness of life. It's a short visual novel, but it powerfully evokes emotions in the brief time we get to know the protagonist and Setsumi, whose lives are made brief due to their respective illnesses. Though the characters are distant at first, there is an intimacy between the them that develops which was touching and the soundtrack and voice track simply enhance the experience. For a doujin work, the artwork is quite well done and the minimalistic approach of presenting the setting and characters allowed me to have a more personalized experience with the story. The rare moments when I actually got to see the Setsumi's face actually felt precious. I really liked this approach. However, I did notice some inconsistencies with some of the art, but it was not terribly noticeable.\nIt's a touching story about two terminally ill patients who are unhappy with their situation, who go on a search for a place that they can die peacefully. It's a tear-jerking story and it is well worth the time.

reviewText:
This is a lovely VN to read but be warned it may make you cry and get upset.

The story itself is a sad one, two girls who are terminally ill struggling holding onto life and confused about what to do. Not wanting to die at their homes or the hospital they are in they escape. The girl you meet is quiet and mysterious and while you journey blindy after escaping the hopsital wing for terminally ill patients you try to get to know her more. I didn't get through it all due to getting upset, the girl talks about death a lot, suicide too, but she is confused on the matter, something I have a issue with too.

The extras such as the soundtrack is a lovely addition if you are tired of reading and just want to hear some calm and nice music.

I highly recommend it but yeah it might upset some people more than others.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu is a Japanese Visual novel, and thats a about it. Nothing ground breaking with the gameplay.
Anyways on to the review





Narcissu is a beautifully done visual novel even though theres any visuals to look on to. It is it's on Text that makes it pretty.


***** SPOILER ALERT MUTHA ♥♥♥♥AS *****

Story:

The story isn't anything complicated just terminally ill patients that will die one day in the hospice they're in.
The girl ends up saying I don't want to die here or at home" which inspires  you (The main character) to bring her on a journey when your dad bring you his ♥♥♥♥ing car for no apparent reason (Look i skipped alot of dialouge in the beginning but trust me it gets a hell of alot better.). Then the two of you the Girl and you go on a road trip to die in a better place. At first I thought this was going to very boring. Oh my

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OMG!!! This is a masterpiece all in it's on right. It really is a said story, but I also think it's a story about choosing your own way to leave this world. And at the end, when Setsumi went into the see in the final chapter it made me cry so damn hard. I was hoping that the main character would stop her cuz I could see them being a lovely couple. All in all bravo this game has so much emotional depth to it that I really enjoyed it. I also think that this game will pave the way for other games with this kind of narrative.

Also the soundtrack is amazing although as I think about it the soundtrack sounds like it could belong to a Japanese RPG game, which isn't a bad thing the soundtrack is beautiful and fits with the theme of the overall story greatly all in all if I was a major game reviewer like gametrailers or ign, I would give this a 10/10

reviewText: One word: Sad. I'm not gonna lie, the story is REALLY f*ckin' sad. Haven't cried from a game's story since Kingdom Hearts 358/2 Days. Nonetheless, has a GREAT story. Teaches you a valuable lesson about life, and throws feels at you every single moment of the way. I actually found the story to be rather beautiful. It really gets the reader to understand what it's like to feel like you're dying inside. I mainly praise the story, due to how much I felt like it related to my daily emotional mindset. I undergo a lot of daily stress, and sometimes I really feel like I'm dying inside, like I don't know myself anymore. This game brought out that feeling, but showed it in an actual physical scenario. Overall, the story isn't exactly for the faint of heart, but it's definitely a must-have for everyone.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nA mature and painfully saddening tale that will leave you engrossed in your feelings aftering completing it, Narcissu was a great find for me reccomended by a friend. Iv'e only just read the first one and I can say as a visual novel fan I fell in love with this story. Griping, paced well and told with some good voice acting the musical scores really helped set the tone for this story. From the start it captivates you, bringing you along for the feels train. If I had to rate this out of a 10 I'd give it a 8; however, I think it may have been better as just a novel albeit myself enjoying the voice of Setsuna and the wonderful music. For a visual novel it lacked the art  expected of it and at times left me wanting more, as an example where you'd expect a stunning image of Setsuna giving her bashful sour expression" you often weren't rewarded it. reviewText: It's free. It's atmospheric and needs a lot of attention to fully enjoy. Easy achievements. It approaches a very difficult topic that needs more awareness in the world. But I can't recommend this game. Suicide is a very serious, hard to handle topic for a game (or visual novel, in this case), and this story leaves one with the feeling that suicide is okay and the best choice, that it's romantic, the ultimate experience. This isn't the sort of message concerning suicide to send to a world with ever growing suicide rates. That's not all the game is about, I understand, but there's more to life than death, and both these games end in special" deaths."

reviewText:
I'm not sure that calling this a visual novel is a great idea. A novel, sure, but as for the visuals they are merely wide-ratio images. After the first few images it gets to the point where they don't really add much. If they had published it as a website/blog, with the images as headers, then I feel the experience would have been better. and in that format you wouldn't need to worry about clicking through each sentence, or dealing with the sentence autoplayer.

As for the story itself, I think its OK. A bit too depressing for my tastes, but it does seem to capture the essence of what it would be like to live with such a condition. The finality of it is hard to handle, but if you want an emotional story, then go for it. Some of the translations are, as expected, occasionally a bit off, but overall it is very good.

As I've said, clicking through the program [calling it a game would be a bit much, considering it is a linear story] can be tedious, and the program itself is a bit odd. The chapters don't seem to run off each other, it takes you back to the main menu after each one finished. And the addition of achievements is clearly an unwarranted gimmick here.

To bring this together, I've not got any problem with the story. But the game that it is wrapped up in is probably better off not on steam.
voteText: 1 of 11 people (9%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Read the first one, not eager for the second. Painful story of death and suicide, and how we allow immovable realities to dictate our lives, and how we might change them a little by doing ridiculous, risky things. It's not an ineffective novel, but it is a bleak one. I don't come away from this book feeling I know much more than I came into it with, nor will I remember the characters. Nevertheless, it was poignant throughout, and well written. I would say that the author is talented and smart, but this book itself is a well illustrated process of slowly dying while grasping at the last few straws of life, and that is what reading it feels like. I simply can't recommend the experience.

reviewText:
First, probably important for you to know, I read the unvoiced 1st season.

So lets start: It's a non-optional visual novel, in other words, just mashing your mouse button / return key and reading is all you'll find in this game, paired with some sounds and pictures, suiting the story, and a soundtrack, supporting the actual mood of the story. The soundtrack contains - at least, as I guess, after playing for almost 3 hours - probably only two songs, but I didn't recognized this as a problem, yet it worked out really well, since you got to know whether that scene was sad or just glumly just by recognizing the right song. The sound effects also were fine, even if I got somehow scared, hearing - the first sound of a human, not a car or the waves - a girl crying and sobbing.
Coming next to the pictures, I'm somehow unimpressed. I got the impression, that there are too less pictures. Plus pictures barely showed humans, making it very unlively. Also more than a few pictures were used too often. The effect, the soundtrack, containing only a few songs, had, reaches here for the opposite. It formerly tells you yes

reviewText:
I think it's a misnomer to call this a game. It's more of a visual novel you tediously click through.  See EDIT.

I went through the first Narcissu, and tried very hard to empathize and I could not. It was a story trying very hard to cause emotional impact and be profound, but when the supposed family members were uncaring to the point of ridicule, it made the story come off melodramatic making it hard to take it seriously. The girl might as well have a stormy, rainy cloud with a sad face chasing her as she walks.

I felt the pacing of the story was too slow and the recycled background images made it very hard to get into the story. Images should evoke emotion, but when they are repeated ad nauseum, emotional impact turns into tedium. The only defense I can come up with is that, the story was trying to create a feeling of emptiness through the repetition, but it drug out too long to were I felt like ooook I get it, I get it.

It ended up making me feel frustrated, annoyed and over it. I wasted a lot of energy trying to be invested and now feel cheated.

I would love if choices were implemented instead of it being just a visual novel because the idea and the subject matter are very interesting and have a lot of potential to be a meaningful experience.

EDIT: I agree with what is being said in the comments. It IS a visual novel. So, I'll rephrase my complaint to make more sense.

My actual problem is that I didn't actually expect a visual novel to be on Steam and I find it disingenuous that it even is on Steam. To me it was like driving to the video game store and finding a comic book on the shelf. Steam, I think, is supposed to be a market for videogames not visual novels or experiences" like that "game"  mountain [mountain-game.com]. A video game by definition should have some level of interaction beyond just clicking through.

AND AGAIN
date: like I said on the review
recommended: I LOVE the idea and the subject matter and would like if this visual novel was redone as an actual videogame with choice and consequence and more interaction beyond just clicking through. Like for example
hoursPlayed: *SPOILERS* the scene where they had to go the gambling parlor to steal money. Imagine THAT situation with a choice and consequence mechanic. *END SPOILERS* It would be an awesome experience.\n\nEDIT: Fixed spelling for clarity. The word is empathize as in "to have the same feelings as another person". Oh and
voteText: defense [www.merriam-webster.com]."

reviewText: This is truly awful. Very little effort has gone into this and it shows. What particularly annoyed me was the terrible translation. Not so much spelling mistakes, but grammatical nightmares. Badly constructed and run-on sentences, confusing tenses, coupled with exceedingly poor punctuation, all combined to twist my mind into knots when I should have been enjoying a leisurely read. In a visual novel you would think language to be the most important factor, but often you are distracted enough in trying to make sense of the sentences. I really didn't think that would be where the user participated when I downloaded the game.\n\nBecause there is often a confused frame of reference you can be left in the dark over who is doing what exactly? But they told me: that I was going to die." Who and why a colon? "It was the only thing (word) that left my mouth from beginning to end." "There was no way to escape it it seemed." "It seemed there was no way to escape it." Is a much less complicated construction. I did consider the developer used a young teenager for the role
date: and had done an expert job of replicating their moderate language skills. Soon however she reveals her age to be 20 years.\n\nThere is very little to do in the game
recommended: other than advance the text and it's lucky the developer provided a save feature. The story is tedious and extremely boring and the images add very little depth.\n\nI'm not against visual novels because I thought Depression Quest was very well done and had some very interesting dialogues and user-participation. There's nothing like that here
hoursPlayed: and even though it's free it's a hard novel to get through."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start by saying, I enjoyed what I read in the first chapter. I could infer the malaise and hopeless situation that the main characters find themselves in. The chapter ended with a good sense of mystery about the girl Narcissu.

That said, this was my first visual novel. I don't mean to knock the genere, but I was expecting more 'visual'. 20minutes into the novel, and all I saw was rain, a hospital ward, and some tables. I would have liked to have seen more of the scenes that were described by the text; parents, the school mates, the drivers licence. Even when Narcissu is first mentioned, perhaps I could see the back of her head as she whatched the TV?

I realize things will probably pick up as I advance in chapters, but this left a dull taste in my mouth for the genere. I guess it's not for me.

Some features that I would have liked to have seen:
-A save option. So I can stop in the middle of a chapter.
-A recap dialogue. So I can return to a save or chapter, and catch up.
-Full Screen mode, for immersion.

In short, probably good if you like the genere. Personally, I'm turned off. I may try again with something more up-beat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't like how the story is presented.  To start, the translation options are cryptic, so the best option for your language is unknown when you start the game.  I chose Insani because it was the only one I thought was legible as far as its logo goes.  It turned out to be an English translation, but the voice was still in the original language, which meant the voice meant nothing to me.  This is an overly glorified e-book, so I hate the empty, wasted space and the very tiny window.  It seems unnecessary to confine the user/player/reader to a game window when they could be reading the book more comfortably from a full-screen e-reader app.  Oh, yeah, you can't full-screen this 'game'!  Hell, it would be better if I could skip to a specific portion of the story since there's no save option or any kind of actual gameplay (no choices).

Finally, the pictures are generic and have very little to do with the text.  You will see the same images more than once and not really understand why they're shown to you at all.  It's ridiculously lazy storytelling in my opinion.  I expected more relevant imagery from a visual novel.  In the past, I used to watch visual novels like this one which were amazing, but this one just isn't worth my time.  It's boring and implemented poorly.  I've seen better in free Flash animations back in the Newgrounds glory days! Yes, it's free, as well, but it's a big waste of time when you can get better experiences elsewhere without much effort.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I actually love the idea of more visual and interactive novels coming to steam so I fully knew what to expect. I got through the first book and part way through the other. It wasn't bad, but I guess I was hoping for a more interesting ending. The whole first one just seemed like missed potential. I started seeing the same thing in the second one so I just stopped reading. It seemed just as the characters were given an ounce of depth it ended. I know this is free and all, but I don't consider price when I review. At the end of the day it falls short because the author seems to lose interest in his own stories before they go anywhere.

Maybe since it is early access all the stories become more strongly linked eventually, but at the current pace of these I'd say I have no interest either way. Best wishes to the author in the future though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Early Access Version Review)

This is a moving visual novel into which a lot of care was obviously put.  The translation is generally good, although some phrasing is awkward, and the story itself is beautiful and will give you a lot to think about -- the general message, I think, can be applicable/relatable even if you are not in exactly the same situation as the characters in the novel.

For a free work, I was also impressed with some of the extras: several different translations are available as well as the original Japanese text; there is a full set of notes from both the original creator and the translators; and the lovely music is on display in a special sound mode
date:
which allows you to listen to music from either Narcissu 1st or 2nd.

Given that all it will cost you is a bit of space on your hard drive and a couple of hours of free time, this is definitely a worthwhile addition to your library.

*To the devs: (this may have been a fluke, but...) the one technical issue I found was that the game gets stuck at the end of one of the notes (I believe it was the last translation note for N1st): instead of being able to simply click and return to the Notes" menu
recommended: you have to hit the "back" button and then "return to title."  Obviously
hoursPlayed: not a major problem
voteText: but I figured that I'd mention it
helpfulPercent: since the game is still in early access."

I can't possibly recommend Narcissu enough.

The story is beautiful. Prepare yourself for a heavy emotional journey. There are no choices in this visual novel, just a powerful tale about life. Don't pass up the opportunity to experience this story.

The music is moving. The voicing, captivating. The images combined with the flowing story text carries the mood and tone, flowing from beginning to end. The telling of the story is a gorgeous experience... don't miss out on it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I almost never do serious reviews, here's an exception [EDIT] The hell with tables.
But seriously. Having stumbled upon this gem by accident, I found the narrative hard to break away from until I finished up both novels. Narcissu stands out to me in the fact that with most VNs, you get choices, but these are purely novels; click, read, continue. (Autoplay is also a thing, so it can be presented more like a movie.)

The Good
-Characters one can empathize/sympathize with
-Great presentation of a few powerful subjects
-Excellent use of music throughout both novels
-The options of voiced and unvoiced are available, should one want to leave more to the imagination

The Bad
-At points, it might disinterest the reader due to the pacing
-No inclusion of the third novel

The Meh
-Himeko's cheeriness might not appeal to some where it did with others
-Religious aspects, view it how you will.
-Only one overlookable inconsistency between the two novels


9/10, would read again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the few Visual Novels currently on Steam,  Narcissu is an expirience unlike one I have ever had before.  It isn't really a game, and in fact can't really even be considered a Visual Novel in the broad sense of the term.  It literally is a novel; one with pictures, music and partial narration.  This is a sad, soulful piece of art that also tends to branch away from traditional VN expirirences by not having a palphable romantic streak or a hard, action based storyline. Although I am only at chapter 3 in 1st, I am completely enthralled and did start crying at some of the more eloquently worded scenes of reflection.  Again, although I have barely touched the surface I have no doubt that for all the more abstract and open-minded gamers out there who can accept a touching linear click-and-read this is a must.

11/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu 1st & 2nd, first of all, is a short story and not a game. In keeping with true Japanese style if you want to follow the story chronologically you should read part 2 first as it explains how the two main characters come to meet. Part 1, however, is the heart of the story but is also resoundingly bittersweet, so be warned.

You follow along on their journey to find one last moment of meaning in an otherwise fated existence. The voice-over is not complete but when present adds a unique connection to an already emotion packed dialogue. It is, however, the soft keening of the somber soundtrack that accompanies each backdrop that will make this story one to remember.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

About 4 years ago, I recall myself writing an essay arguing against letting teminally-ill patients euthanize themselves, namely because it was a defeatist thing to do, and that it would waste what precious time they had left.

After getting through Narcissu 1, I realize how short-sighted that opinion was.

Narcissu doesn't boast any gamplay at all; but it doesn't need any.

The primary focus of this Visual Novel is Setsumi, a terminally-ill young woman who has been relegated to living in a hospice for 7 years without any hope of recovery, and how the pain of isolation has already numbed her emotionally to the prospect of death.

Enter the main character, who himself has been diagnosed with a terminal condition, and is checked into the same hospice as Setsumi. What follows is a desperate, yet touching tale about how even those who have no more hope can still fight to pursue happiness and the final choice of how their lives end.

I played Part I first, but looking back, I highly advise playing Part I last so that everything ends more conclusively.

On an ending note: there is a good reason why this story has been reprinted and retold in physically form, and you have to play this VN to discover it. This game will make you think about how precious our lives are.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu and Narcissu 2nd have different tones but they're both similar. The writing is brief and the story is linear without choices unlike most visual novels.

Narcissu is about 1.5 hours long if you're listening to the voiced edition. It's difficult to get into because both characters are very jaded (They have been spending their time in the hospital waiting to die.) It's alright for a short read. I found it more happy than depressing based on how the characters act towards the end.

Narcissu 2nd is significantly longer, about 3-4 hours (voiced) and is the prequel to the first story. The tone is different, the characters are much more happy and you're able to learn the characters' backgrounds. Also, the production quality is noticeably higher with more art and has a short animation. Much easier to get into than the first.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've just finished the first story, and let me just say... wow. I don't even know what to type right now; it's been a long time since I've been this depressed. The story is about a male protagonist (who remains anonymous, probably for immersive purposes), and a quiet woman who's a few years older than him. Both have been denied their future. Not wanting to have their final moments in a hopsital or at home, the two run away. Initially with no goal in mind, the two travel aimlessly before deciding to finally set their sights on the narcissus fields in Awaji Island.

Do I recommend this game? Yes, but be prepared to feel sad. I really took a feels trip with this visual novel. Also the music is great- at least a x3 feels multiplier. It moved me and changed the way that I looke at things. Anyway, the less info you know about the game, the better experience you'll have with it- that's my opinion. Consider taking a few hours out of your day to experience this beautiful, yet sad piece crafted by Tomo Kataka.

Note- Give it a go even if you don't like the 'anime' style of it. You will only see the characters a few times- most of it will be just settings; you can also chose to have it unvoiced. Pressing 'a' will turn on auto progress if you're tired of clicking.

Will update after finishing the second story. For now, I'm sorta scared to progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Allow me to introduce you to Narcissu, produced by Stage Nana. There are three visual novels (two being free to play): the Narcissu (the original), Narcissu Side 2nd, and Narcissu 3rd – Die Dritte Welt. (And yes, the story does reference narcissus (daffodils)). I read through the first two and found it very thought-provoking. I will give you a brief summary of the games without giving any spoilers (unless I have no other info), and then I will give you my detailed reviews.

Narcissu:

The story revolves around a character named Yuu Atou, a college-age student (about 21), and a reclusive girl named Setsumi Sakura (age 22). The story is told from the first-person perspective of Atou. The two of them are both sick to the point where they are going to die (there is no known cure for their diseases), and thus they have been confined to the 7th floor of a Catholic hospital, the hospice, where they sit around doing nothing exciting. The boy insists they take off, and opportunity falls in his lap.

Narcissu Side 2nd:

Setsumi returns, but this time, the story is chronologically-earlier than the original. A former-Catholic girl named Himeko, who for a time volunteered at a hospital, ends up meeting Setsumi. Like the first visual novel, the story carries on with the two gallivanting off to various distant places in spite of sickness.

Story:

I played through the original Narcissus first. I’m glad I read it that way – Side 2nd is better in both story and presentation. The first novel is long, and by that I don’t mean text-wise (it’s only four chapters) – I mean it’s dragged out. Not much is really going on. The writer keeps things realistic in that there is no secret source of healing or some new medical technology the characters must find to save themselves. There appears to be no hope period. There isn’t anything to do, hence the characters are seeking something. That’s the ultimate goal – to just get it all over with. But even that goal isn’t existent, or rather, obvious, until the very end. In as much as it lacked direction (Don’t misunderstand me: I appreciated the realism), the little things added up. For instance, how does Setsumi know so much about vehicles (and contrary to other bloggers, it’s not because she’s fascinated with cars)? Why does she have so much money saved up? Why does she want to visit the beach? Questions like these are all answered in Side 2nd. Spoiler: We learn that all of these things are simply ideas inherited from Himeko. Hence, the first story laid the groundwork for the second, chronologically-earlier story.

The story of the second novel is different from the first in a few respects. First, the story isn’t solely centered on Setsumi all the time. It was nice actually being able to see things from Himeko’s point of view concerning her own life. The time given to Himeko as well as her relevance in the story makes the story seem more like it was written about two people, each with their own separate story and each just as significant. Both are the central protagonists, both have their own story, and yet both interact with each other on a very frequent basis. The plot of the second novel develops better than the first: it actually has a direction. Himeko has a list of things that she wants to accomplish, and the mystery as to what those are adds some intrigue to her activities. The presentation of Himeko’s background also adds some variance to the story and is important, given that it shows her lack of faith and helps explain why she no longer refers to herself as Catholic (though she continues to believe in God). Concerning Setsumi, her silent nature is highlighted. Plus, she isn’t portrayed as the reclusive, paranoid character we get in the first novel. Rather, she is simply quiet and polite. Her politeness is not habit, but it isn’t accompanied by the normal cheer typically associated with politeness. Another aspect is that, as Himeko points out, it is hypocritical (note the fries).

Completing both stories in the Side 2nd (Narcissu 1st & 2nd) program reveals tan epilogue and full credits. Rightly so – you wouldn’t understand the epilogue unless you had read both. It was… short, and somewhat rewarding. I wish they would have finished the Himeko story (even though it was implied), but I guess it’s less emotionally straining leaving the ending like this. Note that since the epilogue was created after both stories were made, they didn’t make the same mistake of assuming that walking out with a smile is somehow happy in light of inevitable end.

I can’t emphasize enough how much I appreciated the objectivity in both stories (original and Side 2nd). Let me explain: In the end, I don’t feel a bias towards or against anyone – they are as they are and they believe what they believe. The characters, while I didn’t think of them as real, call for sympathy given their circumstances. They didn’t do anything beyond common human responses. While I don’t agree with Himeko and eventually Setsumi did, I do understand realize that many people see things way and don’t have reason to believe otherwise. Hence, within their own frame of mind, they were justified in doing what they did. As for Yuu Atou, he acted out of the desperateness of his situation. I wasn’t in favor of him escaping from the consequences of his actions, but neither did I condemn him. I was disappointed that he stole things, but it was all in the passing of the moment. Being on the run isn’t justification for acting like a fool, but it is realistic to act like a fool when on the run.

Meh:

As an oddity, Yuu Atou never actually introduces himself. Furthermore, none of the characters really indicate their age. The hints at age occur when Chihiro mentions she went to college and she addresses Himeko as being older. An occasional picture of a character might be shown, but anime-style characters have that funny way of making it difficult to tell what age they are. The images we see of Setsumi seem to indicate she is very young in both the original and Side 2nd novels. She is in the latter since it’s chronologically earlier. However, it seems to me that the story could just as easily have been told if she had hardly aged.

A note should be made about the medical field. The author didn’t do as good a job as he could have about making the world of the hospice realistic. Instead, his primary concern was with story, so the truth about hospitals was neglected to a considerable extent. Care and life in the hospices isn’t as bad as the author made it out to be.

Overall:

Frankly, I rather enjoyed the read. It was very thought-provoking. It was a long-drawn out experience, and it didn’t help that I read it during the only hours I had time each day: between midnight and four in the morning. Take my advice and get some sleep, but if you happen to have a slot for time open between 10 and midnight, let me just say, the cinematic and emotional aura of stories like this is always enhanced at night. Trust me on that.
You should definitely give it a try.

reviewText:
This isn't a game. It is a visual novel. Such a format is rather new to me and I was skeptical. It seemed to me that a lack of material in the form of words would make visual novels just incredibly short books, the lack of mechanics would make the genre incredibly boring games, and the comparitive lack of visual information would make the genre rather drab movies.

Well, it turns out I was very wrong. Narcissu 1st and 2nd are awesome just as they are. The background music does add significantly to the experience, and its pacing would not be nearly as effective to me in a film or book (and it certainly wouldn't fit a game).

It is a moving story about young people in palliative care and how they decide to live, and die. That doesn't really do it justice though. Another review described it better: This is a story of disease and suffering; of medication and adverse effects; of thoracotomy scars and cellular poisons; of the living who cannot help but to die and of the dying who cannot help but to live; of a resting place other than "on 7F" or "at home"

There really is no reason not to give this story a try. You won't regret doing so."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played a decent amount of visual novels in my time. In my time of playing them I've never really encountered a story that hit me as hard as this one did. It's a beautiful story that is not terribly long, and is definitely well worth your time. It includes both the original Narcissu, and it's prequel, Side 2nd. Both are incredible stories.The soundtrack is perfectly fitting. My only real complaint would be the narrow visual style can get kind of hard to look at after awhile, but it is visually distinctive and does look nice. I should note as well that you don't get to make choices in this like other visual novels, but as mentioned previously, the story it gives you is astounding.

All in all, it's a free visual novel and it is well worth a few hours of your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Narcissu and Narcissu 2nd have different tones but they're both similar. The writing is brief and the story is linear without choices unlike most visual novels.

Narcissu is about 1.5 hours long if you're listening to the voiced edition. It's difficult to get into because both characters are very jaded (They have been spending their time in the hospital waiting to die.) It's alright for a short read. I found it more happy than depressing based on how the characters act towards the end.

Narcissu 2nd is significantly longer, about 3-4 hours (voiced) and is the prequel to the first story. The tone is different, the characters are much more happy and you're able to learn the characters' backgrounds. Also, the production quality is noticeably higher with more art and has a short animation. Much easier to get into than the first.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

About 4 years ago, I recall myself writing an essay arguing against letting teminally-ill patients euthanize themselves, namely because it was a defeatist thing to do, and that it would waste what precious time they had left.

After getting through Narcissu 1, I realize how short-sighted that opinion was.

Narcissu doesn't boast any gamplay at all; but it doesn't need any.

The primary focus of this Visual Novel is Setsumi, a terminally-ill young woman who has been relegated to living in a hospice for 7 years without any hope of recovery, and how the pain of isolation has already numbed her emotionally to the prospect of death.

Enter the main character, who himself has been diagnosed with a terminal condition, and is checked into the same hospice as Setsumi. What follows is a desperate, yet touching tale about how even those who have no more hope can still fight to pursue happiness and the final choice of how their lives end.

I played Part I first, but looking back, I highly advise playing Part I last so that everything ends more conclusively.

On an ending note: there is a good reason why this story has been reprinted and retold in physically form, and you have to play this VN to discover it. This game will make you think about how precious our lives are.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNarcissu (& Narcissu Side 2nd) is a beautiful, but sad visual novel game. The plot of both revolve around characters that have been admitted to a hospital level called the 7th Floor." This hospital floor is not your typical floor in a hospital (if that makes any sense). It's a "hospice
date: a place where people who suffer from incurable diseases and will eventually die go to live out the rest of their days. Each story is different from the other, and play out different from each other. However, they are both connected and intertwine with one another.\n\nNarcissu Side 2nd is the prequel to Narcissu. Narcissu Side 2nd tells the story of the relationship between two girls and basically how they spend the summer together. However, they both suffer from the same or similar disease that has no cure and will eventually kill them. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNarcissu 1st & 2nd is a touching, heartfelt story about three young adults who have no future. Each with a terminal illness, they can do nothing but wait for death to come to them. Yet, how they go about it is what gives this story it's true beauty. You feel anger, happiness, sadness, love, compassion, and so many emotions inbetween while reading this. It is impossible to describe with words what it feels like to read something so straightforward, yet so perfectly done with soulful, quiet music and pleasantly soft voice acting. I have never cried so much from reading a story, yet I don't feel a single regret. In fact, I would say I am glad to have experienced such a tale, and will hold it dear to me for possibly the rest of my life.

Pros
+Touching and emotional storyline

+2 games in one
+Free to play on Steam

Cons
-Completely Linear Visual Novel - no choices and storyline has one path
-Very short
-Replay value forces players to play the same story with only difference between having voiceovers on and off

reviewText:
Early Access Review

About 4 years ago, I recall myself writing an essay arguing against letting teminally-ill patients euthanize themselves, namely because it was a defeatist thing to do, and that it would waste what precious time they had left.

After getting through Narcissu 1, I realize how short-sighted that opinion was.

Narcissu doesn't boast any gamplay at all; but it doesn't need any.

The primary focus of this Visual Novel is Setsumi, a terminally-ill young woman who has been relegated to living in a hospice for 7 years without any hope of recovery, and how the pain of isolation has already numbed her emotionally to the prospect of death.

Enter the main character, who himself has been diagnosed with a terminal condition, and is checked into the same hospice as Setsumi. What follows is a desperate, yet touching tale about how even those who have no more hope can still fight to pursue happiness and the final choice of how their lives end.

I played Part I first, but looking back, I highly advise playing Part I last so that everything ends more conclusively.

On an ending note: there is a good reason why this story has been reprinted and retold in physically form, and you have to play this VN to discover it. This game will make you think about how precious our lives are.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Released in 2005, Narcissu is a free visual novel created by Stage-nana. There are two parts to the VN, Narcissu and Narcissu Side 2nd. They are complementary to each other and I highly recommend reading both in order. If you don't read it in order... well it will probably be confusing.
It's very short taking about 3 hours or so, depending on how fast you read and whether you want to listen to all the voice acting.

Visuals:
Art is very minimalistic, and the backgrounds only cover about 1/3 of the screen
Kinda disappointing, but being a free game I can hardly complain.
While there aren't too many backgrounds and CG, the game is fairly short and takes place in only a few places.
So it completely makes sense. There are very very few character CGs and when do appear, it is just at the right time, and at the right moments to complement the story. Super minimialistic, yet effective in it's own way.
Some say silence is an important part to music, and certainly applies here as well.

Sound:
Voice acting is good. Nothing outstanding but each voice fits the character. There aren't too many characters in the first place, but the voice actresses do a good job.
On the Soundtrack, it is quite beautiful. All the tracks greatly add to the ambience; although a bit depressing to listen to alone. For such a short game, there are lots of different tracks. I've seen longer VN with only half the tracks that this game has. 12 songs for the first part, and 14 for the second for a grand total of 26.
It even incudes a few vocal tracks!
One complaint I have is the abrupt cuts in music during scene change, or at the end of a scene. I wish it had some sort of fade. The sudden stop to the music kinda kills the mood the game has.

Story:
There are two parts to the story, Narcissus  and Narcissus Side 2nd
The first part is sort of like an introduction, but the 2nd is what completes the story as a whole.
While it is possible to only play the first part, you owe it to yourself to complete the second. Trust me, you'll feel a lot less depressed :(
The second part definitely wraps up the story and leaves with a glimmer of hope.
The plot is definetly not the main focus here. It is more about the life of each character and their emotions. Struggling with death and hopelessness. Again, going with minimalistic art, I'd say the story is very minimalistic as well. A lot of things are unsaid, giving a lot of freedom of interpretation for the readers. I quite liked this style, and allowed for some thought provoking dialogue.

Beautifully written, and thought provoking, it makes you wonder what I would do in that situation. Could I have the power or courage to be hopeful in despair?

If you enjoy Visual Novels, then go ahead and try it out!
It's free and there is nothing to lose~

reviewText:
What I write:
11/10 for my  eyes which were standing dry after chapter 8. Though finished it a way ago without steam, I still wish to make some hours with steam to make my review persuasive.(LOL) Would recommend Setsumi to my girlfriend, student and project adviser. (though I have none of them)

What I want to write:
Actually I played Narcissu's app a while ago, approximately 2 years from now on an android phone. It was a warm May afternoon, and I got  a 2 hours off after the swimming class and before after-class curriculum. I had only a mobile phone, no homework, no friends around, and nothing to do but waiting for the curriculum. So I found myself so bored that I have to seek something interesting - except playing games on my phone that  I had cracked for several times. I checked google play store, with the keyword that I've  forgotten, and my focus was caught by an app with a cover of white background and a smiling girl. Its  name was “水仙” (shuixian, means narcissus in Chinese). I downloaded it, thinking it was some kind of Life simulation bishojo game, which was a perfect way of wasting time. That's how I found Narcissu, the Chinese translated version.

However, it's Narcissu. The result of playing this Life simulation bishojo game" was that I had totally forgotten what was around me for the next 2 hours

reviewText:
Narcissu is a very touching story about how unavoidable death is.
In the first part of the game the protagonist is a boy who doesnt really have a goal in his life. When he gets sick he soon hears that he cant be cured and is going to die. Because of this he needs to go to the seventh floor of the hospital where he meets a girl who also is going to die but neither wants to die there nor at her home...

The second part of the game is about the girl who the protagonist meets in the hospital. In this part she has yet to be sent to the seventh floor and meets someone who will change her life forever...

The game has a really beautifull story and you can choose if you want to play it with or without voice acting. The developer gave the player this option because he wants the player to be able to imagine the voice but also understands that some would rather hear the text spoken. For this same reason there arent many images of the characters in the game.

reviewText:
I finished the first story in voice-mode.
The reason I do not recomend this is due to personal reasons– I don't enjoy super depressing, sad and slow story-lines with a plot were you know everyone awaits death.

On the plus side:
The art is pretty nice, even though I don't like the 'moe' -styled characters.
The music is calm and sentimental.
It has immersive stories that might bring you frickle little people into tears. I'm not excluded.

Downside as I said:
It's truly depressing, about ill people just waiting to die.
Moe characters x sad story? Personally? No thank you most of the time.

reviewText:
(don't mind my time counter for this game. I played this long before it came out on steam)
A very sad story set in the 7th floor of an hospital. This floor is where terminal ill patients are sent for them to stay for their last moments and our main characters are the inhabitants of this floor.
From this you can already imagine that this is not going to be an happy story (despite the 22 yo lolita)
You will cry. And a lot. The entire visual novel is a story about life and death, which puts in contrast the behaviour of Setsumi, whose hope is long gone, and Yuu, who just arrived and has yet to understand Setrumi true feelings.
This game comes with the second game of the series, that is a prequel, which explains some plot holes about the first one.
While the first part earns points for the originality of the story, the second one looks a bit like a repetition of the previous one so not everyone may like it: we again have a terminally ill protagonist, older than our previous character, who is going through the same that Setsumi  will have to face in the future. The second one is lighter" than the previous one
date: and sometimes a bit easy to predict\nBUT\nWhat you should notice is the completely different kind of ending (which I won't spoil) that they have
recommended: making the first one even more sad when compared.\nTL;DR\nIt's free
hoursPlayed: it's 2 in 1
